CFDocument.title: 2023 North Dakota English Language Arts Content Standards

CFItems.fullStatement: Kindergarten
***Learners will apply foundational reading and writing skills by working with sounds, letters, words, sentences, and texts.***
*Learners will demonstrate knowledge of books, print, and written language and how they function.*
Recognize the front cover, back cover, author, and illustrator of books.
Follow words from left to right, top to bottom, and page by page.
Recognize that sentences have letters, words, spaces between words, capitalization, and ending punctuation.
*Learners will accurately manipulate phonemes (sounds) in the spoken language.*
Recognize and produce rhyming words.
Segment parts of spoken words.
Segment multisyllabic spoken words by syllables.
Segment one-syllable spoken words into two-phonemes and three-phonemes.
Blend parts of spoken words.
Blend two or more syllables into a spoken word.
Blend two or three phonemes into a one-syllable spoken word.
Isolate and pronounce the initial, medial vowel, and final phonemes in three-phoneme words.
*Learners will decode, encode, and connect meaning to word parts and words.*
Decode words with phoneme-grapheme correspondences:
CFItems.notes:
Kindergarten phoneme-grapheme correspondences:
a.  predictable consonants
b.  predictable short vowels spelled a, i, o, u, e
c.  long vowels associated with single letters in open one-syllable words
d.  irregularly spelled high frequency words.

CFItems.fullStatement: predictable consonants
predictable short vowels spelled with a, i, o, u, e
long vowels associated with single letters with open one-syllable words.
irregularly spelled high-frequency words.
CFItems.notes: Regular high-frequency words should be taught in phonics.

CFItems.fullStatement: Encode words with phoneme-grapheme correspondences:
CFItems.notes:
Kindergarten phoneme-grapheme correspondences:
a.  predictable consonants
b.  predictable short vowels
c.  long vowels in single letters in open one-syllable words (e.g., he, me, go).  *NOTE:  Some words will be introduced as irregularly spelled until students learn about open syllables.*
d.  irregularly spelled high-frequency words.  *NOTE:  Regular high-frequency words should be taught in phonics.*

CFItems.fullStatement: predictable consonants
predictable short vowels
long vowels with single letters in open one-syllable words (e.g., he, me, go)
CFItems.notes: Some words will be introduced as irregularly spelled until students learn about open syllables.

CFItems.fullStatement: irregularly spelled high-frequency words.
CFItems.notes: Regular high-frequency words should be taught in phonics.

CFItems.fullStatement: Determine the meaning of multiple-meaning words with phonics patterns that have been taught (e.g., bat, can, pop)
CFItems.notes: The standard focuses on identifying the meaning of multi-meaning words.  Words used should contain phonics patterns learners have been taught previously in standard K.F.8.

CFItems.fullStatement: Orally use new academic, content-specific, grade-level vocabulary, and relate new words to prior knowledge.
*Learners will read with sufficient accuracy, rate, and expression to support comprehension.*
CFItems.notes: Refer to grade-level Foundations of Literacy and Reading strands to assist with text selection.

CFItems.fullStatement: Demonstrate fluency through the application of phonemic and phonological skills.
Accurately and automatically recognize and name all uppercase and lowercase letters of the alphabet in non-sequential order.
Accurately and automatically produce the predictable consonant and short vowel sounds associated with uppercase and lowercase letters in non-sequential order.
Accurately and automatically blend sounds at the word level.
*Learners will write complete sentences and paragraphs.*
Write uppercase and lowercase letters accurately.
Write a simple sentence using subject and predicate, with capital letters, punctuation, and appropriate word spacing.

***Learners will organize and express ideas in a format appropriate for the audience and purpose, focusing on skills involved with collaboration, active listening, and oral presentation of information.***
*Learners will organize and express information in a format appropriate to the audience and purpose.*
Describe personal interests or tell stories orally to a targeted audience (e.g., peers and adults).
Speak audibly to express thoughts, feelings, and ideas.
Use words and phrases acquired through conversations, reading, being read to, and responding to texts.
Use grade-appropriate, conversational, general academic, and domain-specific words and phrases.
*Learners will work effectively with their peers to accomplish a common goal or purpose.*
*Standard begins in sixth grade.*
Participate in conversations by listening to others and taking turns speaking.
Work collaboratively by following agreed-upon rules and simple one- and two-step oral directions.
***Learners will comprehend, analyze, and evaluate literary and informational texts in various formats, genres, and levels of complexity.***
*Learners will read to understand various complex literary and informational texts.*
*Listening Comprehension standard is met in K.R.2-K.R.5.*
CFItems.notes:
K.R.2    Respond to a variety of texts, photographs, or illustrations before, during, and after shared reading or other **text-listening** experiences to compare, contrast, predict, or infer.
K.R.3a  Tell about the informational text, photograph, or illustrations before, during, or after a shared reading or other **text-listening** experience.
K.R.3b  Tell about characters and setting in a literary text during or after a shared reading or other **text-listening** experience.
K.R.5    Determine the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases through read-alouds or other **text-listening** experiences.

CFItems.fullStatement: Respond to a variety of texts, photographs, or illustrations before, during, and after shared reading or other **text-listening** experiences to compare, contrast, predict, or infer.
Tell about the informational text, photographs, or illustrations before, during, or after a shared reading or other **text-listening** experience.
Tell about characters and setting in a literary text during or after a shared reading or other **text-listening** experience.
*Identification of main idea, claim, or theme standard begins in fourth grade.  The main idea is taught in grades K-3 in standard R.3.a.*
CFItems.notes: K.R.3a  Tell about the informational text, photographs, or illustrations before, during, or after a shared reading or other **text-listening** experience.

CFItems.fullStatement: Determine the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases through read-alouds or other** **text-listening**** experiences.
*Learners will analyze, interpret, and evaluate complex literary and informational texts that include a wide variety of genres and formats.*
Identify photographs, illustrations, and labels during or after a shared reading or other **text-listening** experience.
*Literary device standard begins in third grade.*
Use a variety of fiction texts.
Respond to or reenact characters' feelings in a story, poem,or nursery rhyme during or after a shared reading or other **text-listening** experience.
Compare and contrast the adventures and experiences of characters in familiar stories during or after a shared reading or **text-listening** experience.
***Learners will produce clear and coherent writing for various tasks, purposes, audiences, and formats.***
*Learners will engage in the writing process and produce a variety of texts determined to address different audiences and purposes.*
Produce writing through shared and interactive experiences in which the development and organization are appropriate to the task, purpose, or audience.
*Standard for organizational structure of writing begins in second grade.*
Draw and write informative pieces on a topic.
Draw and write opinion pieces on a topic.
Draw and write narrative pieces that describe a single event.
*Learners will develop, strengthen, and produce writing by planning, drafting, revising, editing, and rewriting.*
Develop and strengthen writing utilizing the five steps appropriate to the task.
CFItems.notes:
Five Steps of the Writing Process:
a.	Planning: Generate ideas and plan (e.g., teacher-structured oral rehearsal, graphic organizer, peer feedback).
b.	Drafting: Develop writing from the planning process. 
c.	Revising: Improve writing by adding more details or deleting unnecessary wording or information.
d.	Editing: Improve writing by using appropriate grade-level spelling, sentence writing , and grammar standards 
e.	Presentation/Publishing: Produce a final draft that meets the task, purpose, or audience of the writing piece.

CFItems.fullStatement: Planning:  Generate ideas and plan (e.g., teacher-structured oral rehearsal, graphic organizer, peer feedback).
Drafting:  Develop writing from the planning process.
Revising:  Improve writing by adding more details or deleting unnecessary wording or information.
Editing:  Improve writing by using appropriate grade-level spelling, sentence writing, and grammar standards.
Presentation/Publishing:  Produce a final draft that meets the task, purpose, or audience of the writing piece.
Produce shared and interactive writing with emotion or personality expressed through word choice.
*Learners will integrate appropriate language and style to ensure effective readability in writing.*
Compose a simple sentence.
CFItems.notes:
Sentences must:
a.	Begin with a capital letter and capitalize the pronoun I.
b.	Use appropriate word spacing.
c.	Conclude with a punctuation mark.

CFItems.fullStatement: Begin with a capital letter and capitalize the pronoun I.
Use appropriate word spacing.
Conclude with a punctuation mark.
Identify parts of speech in sentences orally, with illustrations, or in writing:
CFItems.notes:
Parts of speech identified in kindergarten include:
a.	concrete objects such as people, places, or things (i.e., nouns)
b.	words as actions (i.e., verbs) 
c.	color and size adjectives 
d.	the pronoun I
e.	spatial and time relationships such as up, down, before, and after

CFItems.fullStatement: concrete objects such as people, places, or things (i.e., nouns)
words as actions (i.e., verbs)
color and size adjectives
the pronoun I
spatial and time relationships such as up, down, before, and after.
***Learners will pose and revise complex questions, identify and connect pertinent information, plan and prepare an inquiry process, and arrive at a plausible conclusion or solution.***
*Standards begin in second grade.*
First Grade
*Learners will demonstrate knowledge of books, print, and written language and how they function.*
***Learners will apply foundational reading and writing skills by working with sounds, letters, words, sentences, and texts.***
*Learners will accurately manipulate phonemes (sounds) in the spoken language.*
Segment one-syllable spoken words into four or more phonemes.
Blend four or more phonemes to produce a spoken word or syllable.
Manipulate parts of spoken words.
*Learners will decode, encode, and connect meaning to word parts and words.*
consonant digraphs
Decode words with phoneme-grapheme correspondences:
CFItems.notes:
First grade phoneme-grapheme correspondences:
a.	consonant digraphs
b.	two consonant blends at the beginning and end of words
c.	single consonant after a short vowel
d.	soft and hard c and g; s as /z/ 
e.	closed and open syllables 
f.	silent e in single-syllable words
g.	vowel teams
h.	r-controlled
i.	prefixes and suffixes (two-syllable words) (e.g., redo, undo, doing)
j.	functions of y 
k.	contractions
l.	irregularly spelled high-frequency words

CFItems.fullStatement: two consonant blends at the beginning and end of words.
single consonant after a short vowel
soft and hard c and g; s as /z/
Determine the meaning of multiple-meaning words with phonics patterns that have been taught (e.g., sand, match, play).
CFItems.notes: The standard focuses on identifying the meaning of multi-meaning words.  Words used should contain phonics patterns learners have been taught previously in standard 1.F.8.

CFItems.fullStatement: digraphs
Encode words with phoneme-grapheme correspondences:
CFItems.notes:
First grade phoneme-grapheme correspondences to encode:
a.	digraphs
b.	two consonant blends
c.	silent e
d.	double consonants at the end of words
e.	irregularly spelled high-frequency words

CFItems.fullStatement: two consonant blends
silent e
double consonants at the end of words

Recognize and use parts of speech in sentences:

Analyze and evaluate how the author's choice in structure, form, and format (e.g., stanza, scene, chapter, section, etc.) supports the purpose, contributes to the meaning, or impacts the audience.
Analyze the cumulative impact of specific style, syntax, and word choices on meaning, mood, and tone, including figurative and ambiguous language.
CFItems.notes:
Suggested terminology for grades 11-12:
* Satire
* Motif
* Allegory
* Symbolism
* Irony
* Oxymoron
* Extended Metaphor
* Foreshadow
* Allusion
* Imagery
* Metaphor
* Idiom
* Personification
* Hyperbole
* Simile
* Alliteration
* Onomatopoeia

CFItems.fullStatement: Analyze how multiple complex characters and literary elements (e.g., symbolism, mood, setting, etc) interact and develop over the course of a text, interact with other elements, and advance the plot or develop the theme(s).
Analyze the development and interaction of literary elements and determine how they impact meaning, using strong textual evidence to support the analysis.
Analyze how the character or author's point of view is influenced by background, time period, environment, and culture and how it affects the telling of a story.
Analyze and evaluate how two or more texts within or across time periods treat similar themes or topics.

Analyze an author's point of view or purpose and possible biases in a text; compare texts from differing perspectives; and analyze how the author's style, content, characterization, and presentation support the author's purposes.

Analyze the development and interaction of informational and argumentative elements over the course of a nonfiction text and how they impact purpose using strong and thorough textual evidence to support the analysis.
Analyze and evaluate various accounts of a subject told in different media, including determining which details are emphasized or omitted in each account.
Delineate and evaluate how a text's argumentative reasoning, rhetorical techniques, and/or logical fallacies support or undermine the author's purpose and affect the audience.
Comprehend a variety of texts with multiple levels of complexity while developing inferences and providing relevant textual evidence and reasoning.
Summarize and/or paraphrase nonfiction texts objectively, including relevant information.
Summarize and/or paraphrase literary texts objectively, including relevant information.
Determine the main idea(s), claim(s), or theme(s) as they develop over the course of the text and interact with each other, and support with textual evidence.
Determine the meaning, purpose, and impact of words and phrases as they are used in the text, including academic vocabulary, figurative, ambiguous, and connotative meanings.
Develop complex pertinent research questions and narrow or broaden the inquiry.
***Learners will pose and revise complex questions, identify and connect pertinent information, plan and prepare an inquiry process, and arrive at a plausible conclusion or solution.***
Gather and interpret relevant information, from both primary and secondary sources, for a variety of purposes.
Organize relevant information from a variety of sources.
Evaluate the credibility of a source based on bias, argumentative reasoning, perspective, and purpose.
Integrate information from sources using a standardized format.
Reference sources for quotations, paraphrases, and/or summaries to avoid plagiarism and maintain academic integrity.
Generate a citation/bibliography page using a discipline-specific format.
Write clearly and coherently with appropriate content, format, and style to accomplish a specific purpose for a target audience.
*Learners will engage in the writing process and produce a variety of texts determined to address different audiences and purposes.*
***Learners will produce clear and coherent writing for various tasks, purposes, audiences, and formats.***
*Learners will develop, strengthen, and produce writing by planning, drafting, revising, editing, and rewriting.*
Develop and strengthen writing through the writing process to produce a quality product for a specific purpose and audience.
Integrate vocabulary and figurative language to create a particular style and/or voice which supports the purpose of writing.
*Learners will integrate appropriate language and style to ensure effective readability in writing.*
Use varying syntax (phrases, clauses, and sentence types) to convey specific meanings and add variety and interest.
Apply language knowledge for a specific task, purpose, intention, and audience, resolving issues of usage as needed.
CFItems.notes:
Language knowledge to be applied:
a.	Use varying syntax (phrases, clauses, and sentence types) to convey specific meanings and add variety and interest.
b.	Recognize and choose between active and passive voice based on context.
c.	Use dashes, brackets, ellipsis, and other punctuation for advanced types and purposes of writing.
     * Use periods with declarative and imperative sentences, question marks with interrogative sentences, and exclamation points with exclamatory sentences.
     * Use commas before coordinating conjunctions, to separate individual words in a series, and to indicate dialogue.
     * Use quotation marks to indicate dialogue, quoted material, and titles of works.
     * Use colons, semicolons, parenthesis. 		 
d.	Follow standard grammar conventions mastered in previous grades.

Parts of speech studied in previous grades include:

Nouns - regular plural, common, proper, irregular plural, concrete, abstract, possessive, irregular possessive
Verbs - tenses( past, present, future, perfect, progressive, irregular past participle used to identify settings, times, and sequences), types of verbs (linking, action, helping) and role in sentences
Adjective - descriptive, articles (a, an, the) as adjectives, possessive, comparative and superlative
Pronouns - singular and plural and the nouns replaced, possessive and the nouns replaced (antecedents), relative, avoid misplaced modifiers, avoid vague pronouns, intensive, reflexive
Adverbs - -ly adverbs, adverbs of frequency
Conjunctions - coordinating (i.e., for, and, nor, but, or, yet, so), correlative
Prepositions and prepositional phrases

Grammar concepts studied in previous grades include:

Simple subjects and predicates of sentence
Complete subjects and predicates of sentence
Subject and verb agreement
Pronoun and antecedent agreement
Clauses and phrases
Independent and dependent clauses
Recognition and correction of inappropriate fragments and run-ons
Follow parallel structure

CFItems.fullStatement: Create a logical organizational structure:
CFItems.notes:
Organizational structure must include:
a.	a relevant introduction,
b.	transitional words or phrases to connect the major sections, paragraphs, and sentences creating a unified whole, and 
c.	an appropriate and thoughtful conclusion.

CFItems.fullStatement: Include a relevant introduction.
Include transitional words or phrases to connect the major sections, paragraphs, and sentences creating a unified whole.

Write to inform an audience and to explain complex information by creating a clear thesis and providing supporting claims, details, and evidence from a variety of relevant and reliable sources within discipline-specific structures utilizing different mediums to provide clarity and context.
Write to persuade an audience.
CFItems.notes:
Write to persuade an audience by:
a.	establishing relevant context,
b.	stating a clear position/thesis,
c.	incorporating valid and reliable evidence from a variety of sources to support specific claims and to refute counterclaims, 
d.	using logical reasoning to avoid fallacies, and
e.	integrating rhetorical techniques and appeals.

CFItems.fullStatement: Establish relevant context.
State a clear position/thesis.
Incorporate valid and reliable evidence from a variety of sources to support specific claims and to refute counterclaims.
Use logical reasoning to avoid fallacies.

Write to convey real experiences, imaginary events, and poetic expressions by using creative writing techniques, such as narrative, dialogue, sensory details, figurative language, and symbolism to engage an audience.
Ask and respond to questions to propel discussion.
Include an appropriate and thoughtful conclusion.
Integrate rhetorical techniques and appeals.
Identify the point of view of a story.
